attributes.title: A physical Stock take
attributes.description:
After stock reconciliation it was confirmed that physical stock quantities for most stock items either matched or showed minimal variance when compared to the book balance, except for the following stock items which recorded significant variance: -

  • Packing Materials had a cumulative positive variance of 1,871 pieces.

  • Bread stock had a negative variation of 44.5 loaves.

·         The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation:
• The branch management needs to tighten bread control and poly bags controls to reduce the variation noted. Also, operation manager to increases frequencies of spot checks on production process and stock issuance.

  • By proactively addressing this issue, it will improve stock management and reduce the risk of stock loss.
attributes.effect: The finding of the physical stock take reflected a strong stock control, with most of the stock showing either zero or minimal variance between the physical quantities and book balance. However, significant variance noted on packing materials (+1,871), and bread stock (-44.50) shows some gaps on supervisory oversight and accountability, stock issuance and returns process and stock tracking and recording.

value: We will follow up on stock items with variations to ensure those variations are eliminated and stock records are accurately going forward

• The positive variance observed in poly bags may have resulted from overstated of production poly bags damage records. The Branch Manager should ensure that damaged items are accurately recorded.

  • Other stock items appear to be well controlled, which can be attributed to proper handover procedures and consistent daily stock monitoring.

·   In a prior report dated 21st March 2025 Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread +14 loaves, White flour +11.861 kg, Brown flour -26.443kg, Wheat Bran +5.869 kg, Polybags +3,561 pieces. The rest of stocks items had minimal variances.
Previous
A physical stock take was conducted on 28 April 2025. The exercise involved physically counting all stock items held at the branch and comparing these counts with the book balance.

The overall outcome of the stock take exercise demonstrates sound inventory management. Nonetheless, the discrepancies observed in packing materials and bread stock warrant closer monitoring and tighter controls. It is recommended that the stock issuance and return processes be reviewed, with enhanced accountability measures put in place to prevent recurring variances and ensure stock integrity.
Operations/Production Department

The objective of this stock take was to verify the accuracy of inventory records, ensure the existence and condition of stock items, and identify any variances between the physical count and the system balances.

attributes.title: Analysis of Poly bags Damages
attributes.description:
·         The following were the findings: -

·  A total of 17,617 poly bags were deducted from the poly bags inventory, reportedly due to damages incurred during packing process.

·   Over the same period, 10,893 pieces were sent to the crushing department, resulting to a variance of 6,724 pieces.

· This variance suggests intentional overstatement of poly bags damages to conceal inventory shortfalls/loss, indicting weakness on control.

· The percentage of poly bag damage against total production was 2.52%, which is above the expected threshold and suggests inefficiencies in material handling.

·         The table below summaries the findings: -

Analysis of the production vs poly bags damages

Analysis of the poly bags qty stock out Vs Qty to crushing store
attributes.recommendation:
• The branch should enhance controls around the packing area to minimize poly bag damages. This includes training staff on proper handling.

  • The operations team should establish an acceptable damage threshold (e.g., a percentage benchmark relative to production) to guide and monitor inventory losses. The absence of such a standard creates room for misuse or abuse at the branch level.

  • The branch must uphold integrity by ensuring that only actual damages are recorded. Any form of record manipulation is a serious breach of the company’s code of conduct, and appropriate disciplinary action should be taken against those found responsible.
attributes.effect:
The unaccounted variance of 6,724.00 poly bags between SAP stock-out and physical dispatch indicates a potential loss or misappropriation of company assets and highlights gaps in inventory controls at the branch level.

· By overstating poly bags indicate a manipulation of the records intentional to conceal a short fall or theft.

·  The poly bag damage rate of 2.52% is abnormally high and results in increased costs of packaging materials, negatively impacting profitability. This suggests a need to review handling procedures, storage conditions, and packaging processes.

value: We will ensure that poly bags are recorded by the slicer at the end of each shift to improve accuracy and accountability
I will conduct periodic physical verification of damaged poly bags to ensure that the reported quantities align with records

An analysis was conducted on poly bag damages for the month of April 2025, following observations made during the physical stock take which revealed a positive stock variation in poly bag inventory. This discrepancy prompted a closer review to determine whether the variation could be attributed to poly bags damages stock out.

The audit revealed that the quantity of poly bag damages stock-out were frequently overstated, potentially to conceal stock shortfalls or losses. Also no damage thresholds as be set to control poly bags usage. The absence of such controls increases the risk of loss or misuse of company assets.

We recommend that the operations team set clear usage limits and implement monitoring controls to enhance accountability, reduce wastage, and safeguard inventory integrity.
Operations/Production Department

The objective of the review was to

  1. Assess the accuracy and authenticity of the records of the production poly bags damage

  2. Verify whether the quantity of production damaged poly bags stock-outs matched the quantity physically sent to the crushing department.

  3. Establish the percentage of poly bag damages in relation to actual production over the reviewed period

attributes.title: Bread Weight
attributes.description: · Results from the sample indicated instances of underweight across all the varieties tested, which indicated a widespread issue in weight control during production. The table below illustrates the findings: -
attributes.recommendation: ·   Bread weight control should be enhanced throughout the production process from dividing area to the packing section to ensure that all loaves packed meet the required standard weight.
attributes.effect: ·       Failure to meet regulator weight standards could result in compliance penalties, consumer complaints and loss of brand trust.

value:
• Underweight issues were caused by overcooling of bread, which resulted from the slow speed of the slicers.

  • We are taking steps to improve slicer performance to prevent overcooling and maintain accurate bread weights

  • Additionally, production staff are being sensitized on the importance of timely slicing to reduce cooling time and ensure compliance with weight standards.

· The underweight loaves were caused by overcooling of the bread, resulting from the slow speed of the slicers and inadequate supervision. However, the underweight loaves should have been identified and salvaged.

·      Appropriate action will be taken to address the negligence observed.
During the prior audit dated 5th April 2025 from the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 400g CT – 31%, 800g W  - 8%, 400g SN - 16%, 400g Barrel - 33%, 600g W – 30%.
Previous
A random sample of bread produced and packed in the branch was selected and weighed
Bread controls were not strong ensure zero underweight.
Operations/Production Department

·    The objective was to verify compliance with the permissible weight standards (e.g. 200g, 400g. 600g. 800g, and 1.5g) as prescribed by weight and measures department and the company internal policy.

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
The audit covered the period from 1 April 2025 to 28  April 2025, and the following were noted: -

v  Production damage: Averaged 0.23% of the production damage, which is above the acceptable limit of 0.20%. The deviation resulted in a revenue loss of Ksh.11,660.00.

v  Market damage: - Averaged 0.58% of total sales, slightly exceeding the standard threshold of 0.50%, which resulted in revenue loss of Ksh.36,621.13.

v  A total of 549 loaves where Oven damages were excluded from production damages rate calculation.

           Table 1 Analysis of Production Damages

                     Table 2 Analysis of Market Damages
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should strengthen controls over production and distribution processes to reduce both production damage and market returns. This can be achieved by ensuring that all bread produced meets quality standards and by strictly adhering to established production and handling procedures. Consistent application of these standards will help minimize avoidable losses and improve overall efficiency
attributes.effect:
There is a need to tighten controls and monitoring to production process to reduce wastage and financial loss.

Market damages are slightly above the allowable rate, but the financial loss is significant, and it indicates a need for stronger postproduction and distribution controls.

Oven damage is significant and must be addressed by ensuring that the ovens operate efficiently and that preventive maintenance is routinely performed.

value: We will strengthen production processes to enhance the overall quality of bread and reduce damage. In addition, staff will retrain on proper handling to minimize production and market related damages.
We will tighten the production process to minimize production damage.
During the prior audit it was noted that production damage was 0.27 % of the total production while market damage was 0.54% of the total sales.
Previous
Production and market damages were reviewed for the period from 1st April 2025 to 27th April 2025.
We found that production process were not strong as indicated by high rates of the production damages and market damages.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to assess whether the branch was operating within the set standards of 0.20% for production damage and 0.50% for market damage.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·         Below is a summary of the findings.

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  The average yield was 191.27 loaves per bag which was within the acceptable limit.

v  Average production was 171.25 bags per day, which is 87.82% of the daily target of 195 bags.

v  Only 6 remixes were recorded over the audited period.

v  The quantities of bread recorded in the mixing chart summary matched accurately with the figures transferred to the cash flow during the audit period.

·         The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart
attributes.recommendation: The branch should strive to ensure that they attain their production target by boosting sales
attributes.effect:
The branch’s average production fell below the set daily target, indicating underutilization of production capacity.

While other process controls (e.g., yield and utto usage) were well maintained, the gap in output performance may affect revenue and overall efficiency.

value: ·       Production is below the set target because of low sales that prompt shift cuts to control bread balance.

The branch targets achievement has always been affected by low sales.

Sales representatives are urged to open more depots to increase sales.

During the prior audit, it was noted that, utto consumption stood at 100 %, average yield was 190.92 loaves per bag, and average production was 124 bags per day.During the prior audit, it was noted that, utto consumption stood at 100 %, average yield was 190.92 loaves per bag, and average production was 124 bags per day.
Previous
An analysis of mixing chart and mixing chart summary was conducted for the period 1st April 2025 to 28th April 2025
Raw materials was properly uses as per the BOM.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to assess whether raw materials consumption was in line with the Bill of materials (BOM) and whether set yield and quality standards were met.

attributes.title: Cash Verifications
attributes.description:
The total cash physically counted was Ksh. 136,665.40, which reconciled with the expected cash balance.

There were pending IOUs amounting to Ksh.10,600 for unpaid bread sold to EALA legislator.

At the time of the check, no cash was held for NSSF or SHA remittances
attributes.recommendation: The branch should continue to advocate for good cash asset controls.
attributes.effect:
The cash office is adequately managed thus the cash at the branch is adequately safeguarded.

The cash office is being effectively managed, and the funds are well safeguarded.

A pending IOU dated 19 April 2025 was identified, indicating non-compliance with the company’s 3-day IOU clearance policy.

value: Cash is okay.
Cashiers are encouraged to maintain good control.
In a prior audit report, all the cash was well accounted for.
Previous
Internal audit conducted a spot check was conducted at the branch cash office on 30th April 2025.
The cash control in place were strong.
Operations/Production Department
The objective was to verify whether the reported cash balance was properly accounted for and adequately safeguarded.
